column1: Whole Person Physiome Table for Male Reproductive System

List physiological functions as a hierarchy, starting with the body system in Function/1 (this should be the same as the table name), a major life function in Function/2, and more specific functions in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. Place limited explanatory text if needed in Function/Notes. Each function should include a ID from Gene Ontology (GO) if possible or another standard ontology. The LABEL column is the label for that ID as it appears in that ontology.
column26: Provide a very brief description (a few words) of the specific processes that occur during the corresponding function (e.g., a chemical reaction, physical change, feedback loop, etc.).
column30: Indicate the time scale category for this process: milliseconds, seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, years.
column31: List anatomical structures involved in the physiological function as a hierarchy, starting with an organ in Structure/1, part of an organ in Structure/2, and smaller sub-parts in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use UBERON if possible or FMA as an alternative ontology.
column55: OPTIONAL: Cell (with ID if possible) to specify certain tissues or cell types within the anatomical structure
column61: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List clinical measures, such as laboratory tests, vital signs, or radiology studies, related to the physiological function. These columns are simple lists and are NOT hierarchical. Include an ID for the measurement, such as a LOINC code, if known. Add more columns if needed.
column73: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List other interacting physiological functions. These columns are simple lists and NOT hierarchical. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use Gene Ontology (GO) if possible.
column85: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will list body states or conditions that change the physiological process. (e.g., "fed", "fasted")
column87: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will indicate the changes that occur during the corresponding body states. (e.g., "increase", "decrease")
column89: REQUIRED. Enter references in support of the information on this row. The ID column should include a standard identifier, such as a DOI or ISBN. The optional CHAPTER column should be used to list the relevant chapters in a book. The optional NOTES column can be used to clarify which part of the row the reference is for, such as a reference about the anatomical structures involved in the function rather than the interactions. Add more sets of reference columns if needed, making sure to include the ID column.

column26: Process
column28: Process Logic

column26: parvocellular neurons release somatostatin and dopamine to inhibit the anterior pituitary
column28: IF somatostatin IS HIGH -> DECREASE [anterior pituitary hormones] secretion
IF dopamine IS HIGH -> DECREASE [anterior pituitary hormones] secretion

column8: positive regulation of skeletal muscle tissue growth
column26: testosterone leads to male pattern muscle growth
column28: IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE muscle growth

column26: GnRH stimulates LH and FSH release from the anterior pituitary
column28: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND pulsatile -> INCREASE lh secretion
column29: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND continuous -> DECREASE lh secretion

column28: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND pulsatile -> INCREASE fsh secretion
column29: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND continuous -> DECREASE fsh secretion

column26: GnRH is released in a pulsatile manner; continuous GnRH secretion is suppressive
column28: gnrh release pattern = sinusoidal

column26: LH triggers testosterone production in males; dual exponential half life of 40 minutes and 120 minutes in circulation
column28: IF lh IS HIGH AND (sex = MALE) -> INCREASE testosterone secretion

column26: LH is released in a pulsatile manner; triggers testosterone production in males
column28: luteinizing hormone release pattern = sinusoidal

column26: FSH increases spermatogenesis in the Sertoli cell; dual exponential half life of 4 hours and 3 days
column28: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND pulsatile -> INCREASE fsh secretion
column29: IF gnrh IS HIGH AND continuous -> DECREASE fsh secretion

column26: serves as a precursor to estrogen
converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
converts androstenedione and testosterone to estrogen
promotes internal and external male genitalia development; spermatogenesis; bone and muscle growth; secondary sexual characteristics
column28: IF lh IS HIGH -> INCREASE testosterone secretion
IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE male primary sexual characteristic development
column29: IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE male secondary sexual characteristic development

column28: IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE spermatogenesis
IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE bone growth
IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE muscle growth

column26: inhibits FSH release; indirect marker of Sertoli cell activity
column28: IF inhibin b IS HIGH -> DECREASE fsh secretion

column26: causes regression of Müllerian ducts in male development
sertoli cells in the seminiferous tubules generate spermatozoa
column28: IF fsh IS HIGH -> INCREASE spermatogenesis

column26: spermatozoa mature and increase motility as they progress through the epididymis
spermatozoa move through the epididymis through the vas deferens en route to the seminal vesicle
column27: spermatozoa MOVE FROM epididymis TO vas deferens AND FROM vas deferens TO seminal vesicle

column26: mature spermatozoa remain in the seminal vesicle until ejaculation
70% of the seminal plasma is formed by the seminal vesicle

column4: development of male secondary sexual characteristics
column5: development of male secondary sexual characteristics
column26: testosterone is converted to DHT in the prostate
column28: IF testosterone IS HIGH -> INCREASE dht secretion

column26: prostate bulbourethral glands secrete ejaculate fluid during coitus; it is not stored
column28: IF (coitus = TRUE) -> INCREASE ejaculate fluid secretion

column26: parasympathetic ganglia innervate corpus cavernosum, release ACh and NO to promote vasodilation
column27: pelvic parasympathetic nerve INNERVATES corpus cavernosum
column28: IF (parasympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE acetylcholine secretion
column29: IF (parasympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE nitric oxide secretion

column28: IF acetylcholine IS HIGH -> INCREASE vasodilation
column29: IF nitric oxide IS HIGH -> INCREASE vasodilation

column26: sympathetic ganglia innervate ejaculatory ducts
column27: hypogastric nerve INNERVATES ejaculatory duct smooth muscle
column28: IF (sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE ejaculatory duct smooth muscle contraction

column32: smooth muscle tissue layer of ejaculatory duct

column26: penis has afferent sensory information transmitted through sensory pudendal nerve
motor pudendal nerve innervate striated bulbospongiosus penile muscles
column27: motor pudendal nerve INNERVATES striated bulbospongiosus
column28: IF (sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE striated bulbospongiosus contraction

column26: corpus cavernosum relaxes to allow blood to flow in
column28: IF (pelvic parasympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE corpus cavernosum relaxation
column29: IF (corpus cavernosum dilation = TRUE) -> INCREASE blood flow FROM cavernosal artery TO corpus cavernosum

column26: corpus spongiosum dilates
column28: IF (pelvic parasympthetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE corpus spongiosum dilation
column29: IF (corpus spongiosum dilation = TRUE) -> INCREASE blood flow FROM perineal artery TO corpus spongiosum

column27: deep dorsal vein DRAINS corpus cavernosum
column28: IF (pelvic parasympthetic outflow = FALSE) -> DECREASE corpus cavernosum relaxation
IF (pelvic parasympthetic outflow = FALSE) -> DECREASE corpus spongiosum dilation

column26: motor pudendal nerve innervate striated bulbospongiosus penile muscles and contributes to force of ejaculation
column27: motor pudendal nerve INNERVATES striated bulbospongiosus

column26: sympathetic innervation from the hypogastric nerve (via epinephrine) causes contraction of the smooth muscle of the distal epididymis and vas deferens
column27: hypogastric nerve INNERVATES epididymis smooth muscle AND vas deferens smooth muscle
column28: IF (hypogastric sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE norephinephrine release
IF (hypogastric sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE epididymis smooth muscle contraction
IF (hypogastric sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE vas deferens smooth muscle contraction

column26: movement of seminal plasma from prostatic urethra to penile urethra
column27: seminal plasma MOVES FROM prostatic urethra TO penile urethra

column26: sympathetic outflow from T10-L2 release norepinephrine to induce sphincter constriction
column27: thoracic sympathetic nerve INNERVATES internal urethral sphincter
column28: IF (thoracic sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE urinary sphincter contraction

column26: internal urethral sphincter of the bladder by sympathetic innervation prevents movement of ejaculate into urinary bladder
column28: IF (thoracic sympathetic outflow = TRUE) -> DECREASE (urine MOVES FROM bladder TO urethra)
column31: internal urinary sphincter of the bladder

column26: spinal cord reflex via afferents through S2-S4, efferent activity via motor pudendal nerve. Results in rhythmic contraction of ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus
column27: sacral spinal nerve SENSES penile urethra

column26: spinal cord reflex via afferents through S2-S4, efferent activity via motor pudendal nerve. Results in rhythmic contraction of ischiocavernosus, bulbospongiosus
column27: motor pudendal nerve INNERVATES ischiocavernosus AND bulbospongiosus

column26: motor pudendal nerve outflow results in rhythmic contraction of ischiocavernosus
column28: IF (motor pudendal outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE ischiocavernosus contraction

column26: motor pudendal nerve outflow results in rhythmic contraction of bulbospongiosus
column28: IF (motor pudendal outflow = TRUE) -> INCREASE bulbospongiosus contraction

column7: emission of semen from penile urethra
column26: semen leaves penile urethra through urethral meatus
column27: semen MOVES FROM penile urethra TO urethral meatus
column28: IF (bulbospongiosus contraction = TRUE AND ischiocavernosus contraction = TRUE) -> INCREASE semen emission
